sentences.text: Presidential elections were held in Mauritania on 29 June 2024. Incumbent Mohamed Ould Ghazouani won re-election for his second and final term as President of Mauritania|president, increasing his vote share by four points.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-04-20 |title=Mauritanian Presidential Election Set For June 29 |url=https://www.barrons.com/news/mauritanian-presidential-election-set-for-june-29-13acef47 |access-date=2024-04-21 |website=www.barrons.com |language=en-US}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-04-21 |title=Mauritanie: l'élection présidentielle fixée au 29 juin |url=https://afrique.le360.ma/politique/mauritanie-lelection-presidentielle-fixee-au-29-juin_A7EENTJ2QZB3TG7UVVBGWJ2AGI/ |access-date=2024-04-21 |website=Le 360 Afrique |language=fr}}</ref>

sentences.text: Under Article 26 of the Constitution of Mauritania|constitution the List of heads of state of Mauritania|president is elected for a five-year term using the two-round system. If no candidate receives an absolute majority of the vote in the first round, a second round is held two weeks later between the two candidates who received the most votes.

references.text: <ref name=Constitution>{{Cite web |title=دستور الجمهورية الإسلامية الموريتانية |trans-title=Constitution of the Islamic Republic of Mauritania |url=https://parlement.mr/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/Constitution-de-la-RIM-ar_8.pdf |access-date=2024-05-16 |website=Parliament of Mauritania |language=ar |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221117072420/https://parlement.mr/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/Constitution-de-la-RIM-ar_8.pdf |archive-date=2022-11-17}}</ref>

sentences.text: For this election, campaigning was held from 14 June to 27 June. Polling stations were open from 07:00 to 19:00 local time (Greenwich Mean Time|GMT).

references.text: <ref name="f24">{{cite news |date=2024-04-25 |url=https://www.france24.com/en/africa/20240425-mauritania-president-announces-second-term-bid-for-june-election |title=Mauritania president announces second term bid for June election |language=en |access-date=2024-04-25 |publisher=France 24}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |title=Mauritania heads to polls as incumbent Ghazouani expected to secure second term |url=https://www.france24.com/en/africa/20240629-mauritania-heads-to-polls-as-incumbent-ghazouani-expected-to-secure-second-term |access-date=29 June 2024 |website=France 24 |date=29 June 2024 |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text: * Mohamed Ould Abdel Aziz, former General officer|General, List of heads of state of Mauritania|President of Mauritania from 2008 Mauritanian coup d'état|2008 until 2019. He is currently serving a sentence of five years in jail, with him being authorized by the judiciary to leave jail in order to present his candidacy file. His candidacy was later rejected by the Constitutional Council, which considered it incomplete, despite Ould Abdel Aziz delivering his documentation. His political movement claimed the Constitutional Council "suffered a coup".

sentences.text: Ghazouani campaigned in part on a security platform, while his opponents accused his government of corruption and clientelism, with Dah Abeid denouncing what he called “a catastrophic management of the state”. Other issues during the election included unemployment, poverty and access to utilities such as water and electricity. Observers from the African Union and the United States monitored the vote.

references.text: <ref>{{cite news |date=27 June 2024 |url=https://apnews.com/article/mauritania-election-sahel-slavery-migration-305e303f3e65a9eb0161682c12b62368 |title=Mauritania goes to the polls with a regional security crisis and economic concerns among the issues |language=en |access-date=27 June 2024 |publisher=Associated Press}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |date=28 June 2024 |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/6/28/whats-at-stake-in-mauritanias-presidential-election |title=What's at stake in Mauritania's presidential election? |language=en |access-date=28 June 2024 |publisher=Al Jazeera}}</ref>

references.text: <ref name=MYCENI>{{cite web |url=https://res-myceni.org |title=My CENI Résultats 2024 |language=ar,fr |website=res-myceni.org |publisher=National Independent Election Commission |access-date=2024-06-30}}</ref>

sentences.text:
{{Update|section|date=July 2024}}
After the preliminary results showed Ghazouani leading in the election, Dah Abeid said that he would not recognize the results of “Ghazouani’s National Independent Election Commission|Ceni” and would hold "peaceful" demonstrations in the streets. A spokesperson for the electoral commission said it had recorded no anomalies or complaints regarding the vote.

references.text: <ref>{{cite news |date=30 June 2024 |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/6/29/mauritanians-vote-in-presidential-election-with-incumbent-expected-to-win |title=Mauritania's President Ghazouani leads in presidential election |language=en |access-date=1 July 2024 |publisher=Al Jazeera}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |date=2 July 2024 |url=https://www.africanews.com/2024/07/02/mauritanias-president-ghazouani-re-elected/ |title=Mauritania's President Ghazouani re-elected |language=en |access-date=2 July 2024 |publisher=Africanews}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 2 July, three people were killed during clashes between the security forces and protesters demonstrating against the election results in Kaédi, which led authorities to block mobile internet services nationwide. Protests were also held in Nouadhibou, Rosso,  Zouérate and Boghé. On July 4, the Constitutional Council confirmed Ghazouani as the winner of the election.

references.text: <ref>{{cite news |date=3 July 2024 |url=https://apnews.com/article/mauritania-election-ghazouani-abeid-protest-7165f12ca95573c91dfaf917ebbbe4dd |title=Clashes between police and protesters disputing Mauritania's presidential election result kill 3d |language=en |access-date=3 July 2024 |publisher=Associated Press}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |date=5 July 2024 |url=https://www.jeuneafrique.com/1585057/politique/en-mauritanie-la-reelection-de-mohamed-ould-cheikh-el-ghazouani-confirmee-par-le-conseil-constitutionnel/ |title=En Mauritanie, la réélection de Mohamed Ould Cheikh El Ghazouani confirmée par le Conseil constitutionnel |language=fr |access-date=6 July 2024 |publisher=Jeune Afrique}}</ref>
